H0.text: Grow taller so that the few remaining honey bees will find them are the once bee‑dependent plants that have the best chance of surviving after the mite outbreak.

H1.text: Changing their flowers so that wind will fertilize them gives the once bee‑dependent plants the best chance of surviving after honey bees have been infected and killed by mites.

H2.text: Plants that have always attracted many other insects as well as honey bees are the bee‑dependent flowering plants that have the best chance of surviving after the mite infection killed many honey bees.

H3.text: Plants that have seeds that stay alive for a long time in the environment have the best chance of surviving among the once bee‑dependent plants after a mite infection killed many honey bees.

A5.text: experiments show that increased honeybee visitation can reduce pollination, both where honey bees are non-native and even where they are native.

A6.text: When honey bees are present as an invasive species in an area, they compete for flowers with native pollinators, which can actually push out the native species.
